In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': []}}\n\n.\n\n\nHere is a short abstract of the idea you should implement:\nSTART ABSTRACT\nTitle: Variational Low-Depth Three-Port Port-Based Teleportation\n\nMini-abstract: We propose the first Pytheus-compatible variational protocol for low-depth port-based teleportation with three ports, directly implementing the target \u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports.\u201d Our linear-optical network uses three probabilistic Bell-pair sources and a single-photon emitter at Alice, a fixed two-layer beam-splitter and phase-shifter ansatz at the central measurement node, and number-resolving detectors to herald and route an unknown photonic qubit to one of three Bobs, with beam-splitter ratios and phase settings optimized to maximize average teleportation fidelity.\nEND ABSTRACT\n\nHere is the full description of the idea given by the Researcher:\nSTART SUGGESTION\nThought:\n  Step 1: Brainstorm 3 Pytheus\u2010compatible ideas tying \u201clow\u2010depth quantum circuit\u201d + \u201cansatz circuit\u201d into a network transformation (not state generation):\n    1) A 2-layer ansatz Bell-measurement for ordinary swapping (already done).\n    2) A programmable ansatz entanglement router (still a swap variant).\n    3) A low-depth variational interferometer implementing multi-port (port-based) teleportation\u2014a genuine network transformation of an unknown input to one of N receivers without feed-forward.\n\n  Step 2: Check novelty & obstacles:\n    1) Overlaps existing examples.\n    2) Essentially sequential swaps.\n    3) Novel\u2014no Pytheus design for port-based teleportation; it\u2019s not pure state gen but a teleportation channel, uses only pair-sources, single emitters, passive optics, detectors, and no feedback.\n\n  Step 3: Pick (3).\n\n  Step 4: Novelty:\n    \u2022 First Pytheus proposal for variational low-depth port-based teleportation.  \n    \u2022 Probes expressivity of shallow ansatz interferometers for complex joint measurements/channel implementations.\n\n  Step 5: Feasibility:\n    \u2022 Uses 3 probabilistic Bell-pair sources, 1 single-photon emitter (unknown input), a fixed 2-layer beam-splitter+phase-shifter ansatz at the sender, number-resolving detectors, post-selection\u2014fully within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics toolkit.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nHere is the proposed target\u2014\u201cVariational Low-Depth Port-Based Teleportation with Three Ports\u201d:\n\nExplanation:\nWe want to teleport an unknown photonic qubit at Alice to one of three remote Bobs without feed-forward, by performing a single joint \u201cport-based\u201d measurement in a low-depth, variational linear-optical network.\n\nNetwork layout:\n \u2022 Sources:\n   \u2013 Three probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083.  Each sends one half to Bob\u2081, Bob\u2082, Bob\u2083 respectively, and the other half into the sender node M.\n   \u2013 A single-photon emitter E_in at Alice, whose photon carries the unknown qubit into M.\n \u2022 Measurement node M:\n   \u2013 Receives four photons (input + three ancilla halves).\n   \u2013 Implements a fixed-depth \u201cansatz circuit\u201d of two layers:\n     \u2022 Layer 1: beam splitters mixing (input \u2194 ancilla\u2081) and (ancilla\u2082 \u2194 ancilla\u2083), plus single-mode phase shifters on all four outputs.\n     \u2022 Layer 2: a second pattern of beam splitters cross-connecting Layer 1 outputs, plus another layer of phase shifters.\n   \u2013 All other optical paths at M are forbidden (removed_connections) to enforce the ansatz.\n \u2022 Detectors:\n   \u2013 Four number-resolving detectors at the output of the ansatz block.\n   \u2013 We define three heralding click patterns: if detector i (i=0,1,2) clicks in its assigned pattern, the input qubit has been teleported to Bob_i.\n \u2022 Optimization target:\n   \u2013 Maximize average teleportation fidelity \u27e8F\u27e9 over a set of test input states (e.g. computational basis), subject to post-selection on the three herald patterns.\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 Port-based teleportation is a powerful network primitive, here cast as a variational low-depth interferometer design problem.\n \u2022 Probes how expressive a 2-layer ansatz circuit is for implementing an N-port joint measurement that realizes a quantum channel.\n \u2022 Scales: add
